WRITING.TITLE: People who have debated religion or the existence of god, has anyone ever changed your point of view, or made you question your own beliefs? What was said?

WRITING.TEXT: When I was a young boy, I was looking for something to eat in the kitchen just around bedtime. I was hungry but I didn #8217;t know what I really wanted so I went to bed. While I was tucking myself into bed my dad came into my room and said, did you get something to eat? I said, I didn #8217;t know what I wanted. He got me out of bed and made me a peanut-butter and jelly sandwich with cookies and milk. When I was finished, he said that when he was a young boy he went to bed hungry most nights, and that he would be sure that I never had to.
Moon-ing. It's about Sam Rockwell mooning himself.
'Just live one day at a time.' Um... What are my other options?

Good times, good times...

Is there any meaning in my life that wouldn't be destroyed by the death that inevitably awaits me? Tolstoy.
Little Father Time, from Jude The Obscure.

Thank you for the explanation. Since the Jurassic World movie I have been hearing people remark that birds were dinosaurs, but I didn't understand why this would be. If I may ask a follow up question: Does the scientific community know if dinosaurs and birds (as we know them today) coexist?

Onions. When I was little I said I didn't like onions. First my grandmother said it was because I didn't try them. Then she said I was a picky eater. She started putting them into almost every meal: cooked, raw, fried, baked. I kept saying I didn't like them. But she forced me to eat them, saying that I would learn to like them. I developed a complex about onions as an adult. On holidays my grandmother puts big chunks of onions in almost all of the dishes. During supper while I am picking through my food, she repeatedly asks, but why don't you like them. When I say that I never liked them, she says, but why?
I'm in the same boat.
Could you offer any more information on people who think this? Like which culture or sect? Or a source? I'd like to research more. I find this fascinating.
When people put cash or change on the counter instead of in the cashier's hand, especially when the cashier's hand is out.
Darren Aronofsky

WRITING.TITLE: ELI5:In the early universe did planets form before stars?
WRITING.TEXT: As mass started to clump together wouldn't planets like gas giants form first until they gathered enough mass to begin fusion? What am I missing? Thanks!
What about rogue planets? I thought starless planets were a thing.
That makes sense. Thank you for the clarification.

A brief stint at a fancy restaurant, my job was to refill people's water glasses. I mistakenly poured regular water in a woman's glass who was drinking mineral water. She snapped at me with a grave and severe tone, 'You have just ruined my water!'
Her level of reproach was so disproportionate it was comedic. When I think about that memory now I see her wearing a cartoon mink scarf.
When a statement ends with, '...and whatnot.' And whatnot what?
Reciprocity and compartmentalize: two words I Porky Pig.
Cowboys and Aliens.
Something the Lord Made. An HBO movie starring Severus Snape and Yasiin Bey.
They are cautionary tales.

WRITING.TITLE: ELI5: Does immunity mean you can't get in trouble no matter what? Are there any exceptions?
WRITING.TEXT: Even for like treason for example...
Thank you! So does that mean someone could admit to murder or something and not get in trouble even if the immunity deal was supposed to be about something else?

Okay, so if you confess to something outside of your deal you can still get in trouble. But it doesn't have anything to do with how bad the crime is that you committed, just anything outside the agreed upon terms.

WRITING.TITLE: I really hope Spider-Man outsmarts Iron Man.
WRITING.TEXT: So far we know Iron Man made the new Spider-Man suit and that Iron Man eventually takes it away. The common theory I've heard so far is that Spidey makes his own low-tech suit, or that Iron Man gives him back the suit after he redeems himself. But I really want a scene where Spidey outwits Iron Man, or at least surprises him with his own ingenuity. Spider-Man is supposed to be super smart, and has been known to impress Iron Man with his cleverness. So far Iron Man is always shown to be the smartest person in the room, and usually several steps ahead of everybody, so it would be really cool to see Spider-Man get one over on him.

That would be awesome. There is a scene in one of the comics where Spider-Man puts a tracer on Iron Man and follows him without him knowing. And Iron Man even says that none of his tech detected it, and he's really impressed. I'd love to see something like that.

Yeah! one of my favorite things about Spider-Man is that he uses his mind to outsmart villains who are stronger or more powerful. I really hope to see him using his wits to win out in the end. I think the best would be if Tony Stark also realizes that Peter doesn't need his tech either to be a superhero, and not feel rebuked but respects him.
Just beautiful!

WRITING.TITLE: Phone, a new Will Self Novel

WRITING.TEXT: I don't understand why posting a link to a new book review about a famous author in the books subreddit would get down-voted.

I am so glad you posted this, I've wanted to talk about my experience with Demons for a while. Brothers has become one of my absolute favorite books, but it took me several attempts to make it all the way through and to finally enjoy it. I'm ten years older now then when I first started and I think that dramatically changed the way I view and appreciate Brothers. But now I've had the exact same experience with Demons. I've tried now on several occasions and never seem to get more than half way through. I wouldn't say it's boring, but it is much more difficult for me. All of the characters make it feel more like an ensemble cast and it is difficult for me to distinguish who's who. Also, I would often read several pages and find myself having no idea what's going on, and I felt like this would happen repeatedly. So far, I would get to a certain point and admit to myself that I am completely clueless as to what's happening. The frustrating thing, and the aspect of the book that would keep bringing me back, are the essays, or philosophical portions that I find really interesting. I am hoping, just like Brothers, one day I'll pick it up and it will just click with me.
Sure,

Kafka can be depressing but he also had a dark sense of humor and enjoyed vaudeville and slap-stick. Some of the absurdities in The Trial are very funny, and were intended to be so. I've read The Trial and The Castle a few times, and with each rereading I've found them funnier. He is absolutely a dark, grave, sad writer but he also had a knack for being simultaneously hilarious situations.
I have! Agreed, sometimes very funny. In fact, The Castle is one of the funniest books I've ever read, also one of the darkest.
Denzel Washington in Training Day. I watched it after he won Best Actor. The movie was pretty good, but I didn't think his performance was anything special.

This reminds me of an old Don Rickles story. He was having a business dinner at a restaurant that Frank Sinatra happened to be dining at as well. Don excused himself from the table and went over to Frank asked him if he would just stop by the table and say hello to impress his business associates. Awhile later Frank stopped by the table and Don yelled, 'Damn it Frank! Can't you see I'm busy!'

WRITING.TITLE: Why is Thanos collecting Infinty Stones?
WRITING.TEXT: In the comics Thanos is collecting the Infinity Gems to impress death. Are there any theories about his motives to collect the Infinity Stones in the movies? I hope they spend time explaining why he wants them other than 'Taking Over The Universe' or just to be the most powerful being in the universe. But if he is trying to impress Death from the Thor movie then that means they already have a history, and it would be really interesting to learn what happened between them to make Thanos want to start collecting the Stones. I just really hope they explain his motives to make his story have meaning after all this build up. Any thoughts or theories?
Yeah! I think it would be really interesting if they had some kind of flashback scene!
I really hope it's not going to be that cliched and boring.

Great post. I submitted a link weeks ago to a review of Will Self's new novel, Phone. He's a writer that I like a lot and wanted to maybe have a discussion. I was immediately downvoted and someone commented that Will Self doesn't like Reddit, so there's no chance of having a conversation about his new book. Really frustrating. Just because the author doesn't like Reddit shouldn't mean that can't have an interesting discussion about a novel he wrote. I just just chalked it up to the internet being the internet. But it would be nice to have a constructive conversation without just immediately being downvoted.
This is the best response I've seen so far, in my opinion.
What is your favorite?
The only other big name actor I can think of is Daniel Day Lewis.

I loved The Red and The Black, though it's been years. I thought his work made a bridge between instructional novels about social commentary like the works of Victor Hugo and the more psychological novels like the works of Gustave Flaubert, and others. Another book you may like is Bel Ami, by Guy de Maupassant.
I pronounce it, Q-teen eighty four.

Well, I feel like there must be some special significance with the new facility. They must of moved it for some reason that's important to the larger story.
have what?
Well that's just stupid.

No, I think it is stupid for someone to point out a grammatical error on an internet comment board without even contributing to the conversation. Comment boards are riddled with grammatical mistakes and people can get along just fine understanding the spirit of the conversation. I do think it's stupid someone feels the need to point out someone else's mistake without actually having anything to say them self. I just wanted to float some ideas about Infinity War for fun, not get nitpicked because I'm not proof reading on an internet comment board.

I think they will be remembered fondly. Personally I don't think good characters can be played out. A character's great moments will be admired and highly regarded, the weak moments will just be ignored. Chaplin's Tramp and The Three Stooges have been in hundreds of films and not all of them have been great, especially the later work of the Stooges. We just look back at there best. Tom Sawyer is another character who is remembered for his two most famous novels, not the several weaker sequels.

Melmoth The Wanderer, by Charles Maturin. It's a gothic take on Faust. The main character sold his soul to the devil in exchange for an additional 100 years of life. Eventually he ends up just wandering the earth for someone to take over his pact.
The Karamazov Brothers. Most powerful book I've ever read. Fun fact: It's the last book Tolstoy read before he died.

WRITING.TITLE: Any love for the Scottish sitcom, Still Game on Netflix?
WRITING.TEXT: I stumbled across this show and was pleasantly surprised how hilarious and consistently well crafted each show is. To me, it is a classic throw-back sitcom with a great mix of strong writing, physical humor and broadly relatable wacky characters. I also love that it is a Scottish program made by Scottish people in Scotland. There can be a language barrier sometimes, but I think it adds to the show. Also the Scots have the best insults. I haven't heard anyone else mention this show here. Anyone else love it?

I'm still working my through, just started season 4. I agree with you, one of my overall favorite things about the show is that you really get a sense that all the characters genuinely care about each other, even if the bicker they're never nasty, and at the end of the day, they have each other's back. Especially compared to other newer sitcoms which can often resort to mean-spiritedness for laughs.
Yup, it has a laugh track.

WRITING.TITLE: Just realized the title The Truman Show is a play on words
WRITING.TEXT: This might already be common knowledge or incredibly obvious but I just realized the deeper meaning of the title, The Truman Show. Jim Carrey's character, Truman Burbank is the only 'true man' in the movie, everyone else's character is an actor in Truman's life. I only put it together while watching Jim Carrey #8217;s documentary about Andy Kaufman. The way Jim Carrey was talking about the his character in the Truman Show it all sort of came together and made so much sense.

WRITING.TITLE: Just realized the title The Truman Show is a play on words

Jim and Andy, on Netflix. Really fascinating.
My opening statement was that my comment might be incredibly obvious. I'm sorry I'm not as very smart as you.

Yeah, I tried to be careful with how I phrased my post, stating first that it was probably already common knowledge or just obvious, and that it was only after watching the Jim Carrey documentary where he makes the connection pretty clearly, did I make the connection myself. I don't post very often, and I pretty much never notice really cool details like this own my own.

I cannot remember the books I've read any more than the meals I have eaten; even so, they have made me. - Ralph Waldo Emerson

WRITING.TITLE: Nobody Learns Their Lesson on The Andy Griffith Show
WRITING.TEXT: Nobody ever seems to learn their lesson other than Andy and Opie. It's actually one of the most intriguing aspects of the show as a whole. With each season Andy becomes progressively more irritated with the bad decisions and poor reasoning of everyone around him. Andy has become visibly dismayed with everyone's lack of self-improvement, or even self-awareness; his stoicism has turned to bitterness, not just because of everybody's constant stream of zany antics, but also, and maybe even more importantly, because nobody ever trusts his sense of judgement, or will even just listen to him, until the very final act of the show. Understandably, Andy has gotten to the point where he doesn't even want to be involved with everyone's lunacy, isolating himself, burying his head in the newspaper, or busying himself at work, not because they're bad people, but because they've never learned to trust him. He's tired of being doubted and treated with suspicion, but also expected to make everything better again in the end. In this respect, the show as a whole reminds me of a very subtle version of The Twilight Zone, with Andy gradually questioning his sanity and asking, 'Is everyone crazy? Or could I be the crazy one?' I may be over thinking it, but I find Andy's character arc fascinating.
Thank you:) He's a good boy.

There is a big shift even between the 1st and 2nd season. At first Andy is a silly wide-grinning yokel, making poor decisions like everyone else, in the second season he becomes the straight man, a much more wise, Lincolnesque figure.
Barney's departure was absolutely a loss for Andy, his optimism went away.

I think you are right, in real life Andy Griffith had also become increasingly irritated with his situation, but that development had interesting implications on the character's trajectory in the show, for better or worse.
The only people I know that are married are Otis, the town drunk, Mr Fowler, the butcher, Charlene Darling, and just once Floyd the barber mentioned a wife.
And also so far only two episodes showed African Americans, both times involved joining the military; one episode showed a Native American; and only one episode so far showed teenagers.
Oh nice! Thank you!

WRITING.TITLE: Based on The Writings of Stefan Zweig
WRITING.TEXT: Have you seen The Grand Budapest Hotel? I just watched it over the weekend, and it's an immaculately crafted piece of cinema. In case you haven't, I'll try to briefly describe the premise: It's a period piece directed by Wes Anderson set sometime during the World Wars, the main setting is, quite obviously, a grand hotel, and the main characters are a fastidious concierge, a young bell hop under his tutelage, and the young bell hop's love interest, a confectioner's apprentice. The aging concierge is also a lothario who seduces the rich elderly women who patronize the hotel, and the women happily welcome his romantic overtures. The story is propelled when one of the rich women dies and bequeaths the concierge a priceless painting. The rich woman's family disputes this endowment and labels the concierge as a scoundrel. It's all very madcap, complete with an art heist, a jail break, and a secret society. But at the very end of the film when the screen goes black and one might expect to see 'Directed by Wes Anderson', instead we see 'Based on The Writings of Stefan Zweig'. Well I had never heard of the writer! I was so impressed with the movie I decided to order some of his books, and boy was I not disappointed. The first book 'Chess Story' was one of the most satisfying reading experiences I've had in sometime. I read it in one sitting, utterly captivated. On the surface it's a simple story of a chess match on an ocean liner, but the characters are fully realized with profoundly deep psychological portraits, and the chess match, quite nimbly, parallels the loneliness and struggle of human suffering, and the fulfillment and promise of human achievement. I cannot give a high enough endorsement of this book and this writer. Would recommend.

WRITING.TITLE: A Book With A Great Beginning
WRITING.TEXT: Last night I started reading The Fortune of The Rougons, by Emile Zola and it has one of the most compelling, strangest opening sequences. The story begins with a description of a simple plot of land, a cemetery located in the French countryside. The cemetery was too small to accommodate all of the mortal bodies in town, so every few years the ground was tilled. The old dead were mixed with fresh soil to make room for newer bodies. Eventually the ground became so saturated with human remains and consumed by bones, it became unusable for burying the dead; The plot was abandoned. After years of neglect the site was overrun by weeds, vegetation; monstrous pear trees grew, feeding off the dead. The villagers were horrified by these pear trees and refused to eat the fleshy fruit they produced, except for the children who happily gobbled them up in secret. Eventually the plot was bought by a developer who chopped down all the trees, cleared the land of weeds, and dug up all the bones. The villagers were happy and relieved at the prospect of progress in their community. But the children were not happy, they no longer had their pear trees which gave them their delicious fruit. In an act of vengeful retribution the children stole bones which were piled up next to the old cemetery, and strung up all of the bones throughout the village in the cover of night. The next morning the entire village woke up terror stricken: skulls hung from lampposts and doorways, femurs lined the streets, tibia and fibula hung from windows, and all manner of unrecognizable bone shards were scattered up and down the storefronts. Doom and panic loomed over the entire god-fearing town: the children had their revenge.

I've read a few of his books and I've always enjoyed them so I thought I'd start with the first novel of the cycle, but I am not planning on reading them all in order, or at least not yet. My copy was translated by Brian Nelson and so far it is quite good.
Thank you, and you're spot on. Maupassant is one of my absolute favorite writers.
I agree with your list. The only other major contender I'd say is Jonathon Swift.
A few others, And Quiet Flows The Don - Mikhail Sholokov, Blood Dark - Louis Guilloux, Schlump - Hans Herbert Grimm, Life And Fate - Vasily Grossman

You may like to take a look at his last novel, Resurrection, it is a good representation of his later philosophy on life and religion, and it is also more approachable at least in terms of length. Or you may like to check out Hadji Murad, which is a masterful novella he wrote later in life as well. Also, The Death of Ivan Ilyich, which is generally considered one of his masterpieces, will give you his thoughts on life and death. And it can be read in an afternoon. Lastly Confession is worth reading too, it is sort of a spiritual companion to The Death of Ivan Ilyich, and also a quick read.
If you're ever in the mood for books that definitely will not end happily, I'd suggest the works of Thomas Hardy.
You would eat an egg that came out of you?!

Read this book years ago. One of the lines that stuck with me was something to the effect of, 'The more he spent, the less money mattered.'

I am not aware of Proust giving advice on writing, or explaining his style, but if you are a fan of Proust already I would recommend reading 'Memoirs From a Tomb', by Rene Chateaubriand. Proust was an admirer of his style, and influenced by his attitude towards memory. In general, if you are ever interested in how a writer developed a distinctive style, researching the writers that influenced them is a good start.

WRITING.TEXT: It just occurred to me those pieces of Thor's hammer are just sitting in the dirt somewhere in Norway.

WRITING.TITLE: I had the most awful dream last night involving a woman that I know and a horse
WRITING.TEXT: I was on my back, she was atop me, straddling my head holding a power drill. She had me pinned down and she was drilling a hole into my cheekbone. The drill was zapping and popping, my skull was vibrating, smoke was in the air and blood was in my field of vision. I could even smell flesh burning. I yelled, 'What are you doing?!' And she said, 'I'm putting a little horse in your cheek.' And pinched between her forefinger and thumb was a miniature horse figurine. She put the horse on the end of the drill and proceeded to auger the figurine deep within my skull.

WRITING.TITLE: I had the most awful dream last night involving a woman that I know, and a horse
WRITING.TEXT: I was on my back, she was atop me, straddling my head holding a power drill. She had me pinned down and she was drilling a hole into my cheekbone. The drill was zapping and popping, my skull was vibrating, smoke was in the air and blood was in my field of vision. I could even smell flesh burning. I yelled, 'What are you doing?!' And she said, 'I'm putting a little horse in your cheek.' And pinched between her forefinger and thumb was a miniature horse figurine. She put the horse on the end of the drill and proceeded to auger the figurine deep within my skull.

I have no idea! That's why I posted here. The whole thing was so vivid and alarming. I thought maybe someone who is better at this sort of thing might have some ideas. I don't even know the person with the drill very well, she's more of a passing acquaintance.
Completely a personal preference, but my favorite Dostoevsky translator is Ignat Avsey.

Hi, I'll try to answer your questions, though some aspects of this dream have become hazy since it's been a few days. She's a petite brunette in her late twenties, about a foot shorter than me. She has shoulder length hair and olive skin. I'd say we're friends, but not very close. She's an artist and most of our association is me in her studio, critiquing and discussing her paintings. She's also a bartender and sometimes I stop in for a pint. And to clarify, I am not her teacher, or a teacher at all, just another artist. I feel that the event took place in my bed, because it was so vivid that it awakened me from my sleep and I felt that I was in the same location. I don't know if my limbs were restrained, but I didn't have use of them. And although some of this may sounds similar to some kind of fetish, none of this felt sexual. It was just scary. I don't know the material of the horse, but it was shiny and looked durable, maybe some kind of metal. And the horse was small, very very small, like something you would need tweezers to grasp: smaller than a pea. I don't have much history with horses. I think they are pretty, but in general they frighten me. I wouldn't want to be near one, and certainly would not ride a horse. But it's not like I have any childhood trauma with a horse or anything. I don't come into contact with horses in my daily life and it's probably ten years since I've seen one in person and close-up. I own a few power tools, and a power drill, but they are not frequently used. They're used just for little household projects. I'm perfectly comfortable using power tools, and I've never had an injury. She was definitely drilling into the cheekbone, just below the eye socket, right where the cheekbone protrudes. And I distinctly remember it was my left cheekbone. I'm trying to think of anything else. I'm a guy, early thirties. I have frequent nightmares. This is my first time posting here, because this dream was so startling and strange. Thank you for all of your interest!

Have you read other works by Hugo? If you haven't, I'd recommend starting somewhere else. My favorite novel by Hugo is Toilers Of The Sea, it's a man vs nature, adventure story with portions of his usual declarative philosophizing. The Man Who Laughs can be a labor at times because of the amount he dedicates to explaining history and lineages. It is similar to Moby Dick in that way. That being said, if you are already a Victor Hugo fan it is definitely worth reading, otherwise French literature has many other options.

Tolstoy is a powerful short story writer. You may be interested in 'Childhood, Boyhood, Youth', it's an early autobiographical work by Tolstoy. It gives a lot of insight on how Tolstoy's early life informed his mature work. As far as 'Brothers' and 'War and Peace', keep in mind that the 100 or 200 pages are the most challenging in both. But if you stick with it, they become incredibly readable; they will engross you, and when you finish, you'll wish they were longer. Happy reading!

It's one of my favorite books as well. I've read it a few times, and each reading I've identified with a different brother. Truly remarkable story telling. Interesting side note: Brothers is the last book Tolstoy read before he died.
If you haven't already, check out Vonnegut. He often has non-linear narratives and stories within stories. Also if you like experimental use of language, A Clockwork Orange is fun.
Your question was answered nicely by Ralph Waldo Emerson: I cannot remember the books I've read anymore than the meals I've eaten; even so, they have made me.
I think Life and Fate by Vasily Grossman is one of the greatest novels of the 20th century. It's what War and Peace was for the 19th century.
Much earlier, but Taras Bulba by Gogol tells the story of the Cossack revolt against the Poles. It's short and great.
Maybe Frasier's son Freddy has grown up and become a no-nonsense cop and hangs out at the local bar, but for some reason he has to take care of an older Frasier and deal with his prissy uncle Niles.

WRITING.TITLE: Question about Thor and Hulk's strength
WRITING.TEXT: Thor and Hulk are shown to be pretty much equally matched physically in Ragnorak. But in the 1st Avengers Hulk punches that flying caterpillar and stops it dead in its tracks. Could Thor have punched the flying caterpillar and stopped it the same way? My guess is that he couldn't. So did Thor get stronger in Ragnorak? Or did Hulk get weaker? And shouldn't Hulk be a whole lot stronger anyway?

I never understood how the Hulkbuster vs Hulk fight ended. The building falls on Hulk and then he gets punched, then it just cuts to Banner on the ship. I just can't believe that last punch really knocked him out. I don't know how else they would have ended it though I guess.
Ah thanks!

Cioran, Nadja - Andre Breton,

If you are part of the conversation, offer your opinion and be respectful. If you are not part of the conversation, let them debate in peace.

You may like to check out Against Nature, by Joris-Karl Huysman. At some point Lord Henry gives a Dorian a book that corrupts him, this is the actual book that Oscar Wilde was referencing. Though the book wasn't named in the text, Oscar Wilde admitted it was Against Nature during his trial.

Wow, those are incredibly thoughtful gifts! You found a keeper! Here's a few other books that influenced Oscar Wilde that you may find of interest, though it sounds like you are probably acutely aware. But just in case, Melmoth The Wanderer by Charles Maturin, who was Oscar Wilde's Great Uncle. Marius The Epicurean by Walter Pater The Renaissance by Walter Pater
I'm not sure of the publisher, but Robert Baldick is always reliable.

WRITING.TITLE: R/books really is the best subreddit
WRITING.TEXT: I don't post often, but I come here every day. As a book lover, I am so grateful this community is so often supportive and generous with their time. One thing I love is that even though nearly everyday a select few novels are posted by people reading them for the first time, either showing appreciation or asking a question. Quite often, Blood Meridian, The Catcher In The Rye, Infinite Jest, Crime and Punishment, Catch-22, East Of Eden, Grapes Of Wrath etc. But instead of being critical or pedantic about seeing the same books, this community just seems to understand that people are constantly discovering these books for the first time, and make a point to be encouraging. This is just a great group of people. Thanks everyone!

Well since you asked, I prefer physical books to listening to audio books for two reasons, I like the ritual of sitting down with a book in my hands, and that with a physical book I am devoting all of my attention to the act of reading, and also that I grew up reading physical books. I can't really comment on ebooks because I've never used one, but I see how they are beneficial to younger people or students that are required to carry many books around school. But I really don't have a judgement about how other people decide to enjoy their books.
Oh not at all, I completely understand. It's not so much that I like that people post about reading the same books, but that when they do, they don't get berated with negative comments.
